data.value: rows with the largest values in
, in descending order. The columns that are not specified are returned as well, but not used for ordering.
This function cannot be used with all column types. For example, when specifying columns with
rows ordered by the given columns in descending order.

data.out:
population      GDP alpha-2
Italy       59000000  1937894      IT
France      65000000  2583560      FR
Malta         434000    12011      MT
Maldives      434000     4520      MV
Brunei        434000    12128      BN
Iceland       337000    17036      IS
Nauru          11300      182      NR
Tuvalu         11300       38      TV
Anguilla       11300      311      AI

data.value: In the following example, we will use
to select the three rows having the largest values in column "population".

data.out:
population      GDP alpha-2
France    65000000  2583560      FR
Italy     59000000  1937894      IT
Malta       434000    12011      MT

data.value: , ties are resolved in reverse order:

data.out:
population      GDP alpha-2
France    65000000  2583560      FR
Italy     59000000  1937894      IT
Brunei      434000    12128      BN

population      GDP alpha-2
France      65000000  2583560      FR
Italy       59000000  1937894      IT
Malta         434000    12011      MT
Maldives      434000     4520      MV
Brunei        434000    12128      BN

data.value: To order by the largest values in column "population" and then "GDP", we can specify multiple columns like in the next example.

data.out:
population      GDP alpha-2
France    65000000  2583560      FR
Italy     59000000  1937894      IT
Brunei      434000    12128      BN
